repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Basically a simplified version of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/19649#issuecomment-1750272564

Looking to get some initial feedback here. Instead of just appending to the message, we might instead want to store the related info in the `vim.Diagnostic` struct, and then instead extend the logic in `vim.diagnostic.open_float()`...?

This PR:
![Screenshot_2024-05-04_21-20-17](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/13141438/bde8cbc2-fbf4-4264-9f5e-fb58a37f2d87)
vscode:
![Screenshot_2024-05-04_21-22-00](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/13141438/efc56625-284b-4242-8a84-d824fa035dc9)

EDIT: PR now only adds the related_information field to the toplevel of vim.Diagnostic (see discussion below). We could then decide in a follow-up PR if and how we should display this to the user.

comment_data.body: `relatedInformation` is an array, so it looks like `ipairs` instead of `pairs` would be better?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -110,6 +110,14 @@ local function diagnostic_lsp_to_vim(diagnostics, bufnr, client_id)
   return vim.tbl_map(function(diagnostic)
     local start = diagnostic.range.start
     local _end = diagnostic.range['end']
+    for _, relatedInfo in pairs(diagnostic.relatedInformation or {}) do

comment_data.body: `location` seems to be a non-nil (required) field of the `lsp.DiagnosticRelatedInformation` class.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -110,6 +110,14 @@ local function diagnostic_lsp_to_vim(diagnostics, bufnr, client_id)
   return vim.tbl_map(function(diagnostic)
     local start = diagnostic.range.start
     local _end = diagnostic.range['end']
+    for _, relatedInfo in pairs(diagnostic.relatedInformation or {}) do
+      if relatedInfo.location then

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- a diagnostic, e.g when duplicating a symbol in a scope.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -42,6 +45,29 @@ local M = {}
 ---
 --- @field namespace? integer
 
+--- Related message and location for a diagnostic.
+--- This can be used to point to code locations that cause or are related to
+--- a diagnostics, e.g when duplicating a symbol in a scope.

comment_data.body:
Chaining a map with a filter is a good use case for `vim.iter`. `vim.iter(related_informations):map()` gives you filter+map semantics combined (if the callback function returns `nil` then the item is filtered out).

Although, is the original filter for `item ~= nil` even necessary? Presumably `related_informations` is an array, so it should not have any `nil` items in it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -97,6 +97,33 @@ local function tags_lsp_to_vim(diagnostic, client_id)
   return tags
 end
 
+---@param related_informations lsp.DiagnosticRelatedInformation[]
+---@param offset_encoding string
+---@return vim.DiagnosticRelatedInformation?
+local function related_information_lsp_to_vim(related_informations, offset_encoding)
+  return vim.tbl_filter(function(item) return item ~= nil end,
+    --- @param related_information lsp.DiagnosticRelatedInformation
+    --- @return vim.DiagnosticRelatedInformation
+    vim.tbl_map(function(related_information)
+      local fname = vim.uri_to_fname(related_information.location.uri)
+      local bufnr = vim.fn.bufadd(fname)
+      if not bufnr then
+        return
+      end
+      local buf_lines = get_buf_lines(bufnr)
+      local start = related_information.location.range.start
+      local _end = related_information.location.range['end']
+      --- @type vim.DiagnosticRelatedInformation
+      return {
+        lnum = start.line,
+        col = line_byte_from_position(buf_lines, start.line, start.character, offset_encoding),
+        end_lnum = _end.line,
+        end_col = line_byte_from_position(buf_lines, _end.line, _end.character, offset_encoding),
+        message = related_information.message,
+      }
+    end, related_informations))

comment_data.body: The intention was to handle the `if not bufnr then return end` path - But thanks for the hint about using `vim.iter(..):map` (the rustacean in me would've expected this to be called `filter_map` though)

comment_data.body:
It's functionally equivalent in this case but imo is slightly clearer (we explicitly return either `nil` or a `vim.DiagnosticRelatedInformation` on all code paths).

```suggestion
      local bufnr = vim.fn.bufadd(fname)
      if not bufnr then
        return nil
      end
```

comment_data.body:
You also need `:totable()` to collapse the iterator back into a table (analagous to `collect()` in Rust)

```suggestion
    end):totable()
```

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
   Add `vim.Diagnostic.related_information` field and fill it with
    `vim.diagnostic.RelatedInformation[]`. Deprecate
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -271,6 +271,10 @@ The following new APIs and features were added.
    |vim.lsp.buf.definition()|, |vim.lsp.buf.declaration()|,
     |vim.lsp.buf.type_definition()|, and |vim.lsp.buf.implementation()| now
     support the `loclist` field of |vim.lsp.ListOpts|.
+   Add `vim.Diagnostic.related_information` field and fill it with
+    `lsp.DiagnosticRelatedInformation[]`. Deprecate

comment_data.body: I intentionally wrote `lsp.DiagnosticRelatedInformation` here though, to highlight the new logic I added in `lsp/diagnostic.lua`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -271,6 +271,10 @@ The following new APIs and features were added.
    |vim.lsp.buf.definition()|, |vim.lsp.buf.declaration()|,
     |vim.lsp.buf.type_definition()|, and |vim.lsp.buf.implementation()| now
     support the `loclist` field of |vim.lsp.ListOpts|.
+   Add `vim.Diagnostic.related_information` field and fill it with
+    `lsp.DiagnosticRelatedInformation[]`. Deprecate

comment_data.body:
`lsp.DiagnosticRelatedInformation[]` does not link to anything in Nvim's help docs so I'm not sure it's valuable to have here in the user facing news. `vim.diagnostic.RelatedInformation` does have a help tag though. Maybe we keep this simple and just say:

```suggestion
 Add a new `related_information` field to |vim.Diagnostic| in favor of
  `vim.Diagnostic.user_data.lsp.relatedInformation` (now deprecated). See
  |vim.diagnostic.RelatedInformation|.
```

     support the `loclist` field of |vim.lsp.ListOpts|.

+    `lsp.DiagnosticRelatedInformation[]`. Deprecate

comment_data.body: Can you also update `diagnostic_vim_to_lsp` to make use of this?

       severity = severity_lsp_to_vim(diagnostic.severity),
       message = diagnostic.message,
+      related_information = related_information_lsp_to_vim(
+        diagnostic.relatedInformation,
+        offset_encoding
+      ),
       source = diagnostic.source,
       code = diagnostic.code,
       _tags = tags_lsp_to_vim(diagnostic, client_id),
       user_data = {
-        lsp = {
-          -- usage of user_data.lsp.code is deprecated in favor of the top-level code field
-          code = diagnostic.code,
-          codeDescription = diagnostic.codeDescription,
-          relatedInformation = diagnostic.relatedInformation,
-          data = diagnostic.data,
-        },
+        lsp = diagnostic,

comment_data.body: See my top level comment: if I understand the code correctly, `diagnostic_vim_to_lsp` already makes use of this, since it already merges the contents of `user_data.lsp` into the returned table. (This is also why the unit tests currently fails, I fixed this now in the latest push)

comment_data.body:
@gpanders what do you think of making the related_information property a iterable or table?

It would allow us to make this lazy, so that users not using the information wouldn't have to pay for the conversion costs here
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -97,6 +97,38 @@ local function tags_lsp_to_vim(diagnostic, client_id)
   return tags
 end
 
+---@param related_informations lsp.DiagnosticRelatedInformation[]
+---@param offset_encoding string
+---@return vim.diagnostic.RelatedInformation[]
+local function related_information_lsp_to_vim(related_informations, offset_encoding)
+  return vim
+    .iter(related_informations or {})
+    :map(
+      --- @param related_information lsp.DiagnosticRelatedInformation
+      --- @return vim.diagnostic.RelatedInformation?
+      function(related_information)
+        local fname = vim.uri_to_fname(related_information.location.uri)

comment_data.body:
any problem with using a less verbose name?
```suggestion
*vim.diagnostic.Related*
```

comment_regular_data.body:
I think instead of extending the message this should go into the structure, otherwise users can't customise this. (And I'd wager there's a bunch who don't want this in the message).

There are also actions where we send the diagnostic back to the server and I think for the server to be able to re-associate the payloads with their internal state the diagnostic mustn't change.

> I think instead of extending the message this should go into the structure, otherwise users can't customise this. (And I'd wager there's a bunch who don't want this in the message).
> 
> There are also actions where we send the diagnostic back to the server and I think for the server to be able to re-associate the payloads with their internal state the diagnostic mustn't change.

Sounds fair - I changed the PR so that now it only adds the `relatedInformation` field to the toplevel of `vim.Diagnostic`. We could then decide in a follow-up PR if and how we should display this to the user.

If this looks good, I'll add a test to `diagnostic_spec.lua` that covers this new field.

`vim.Diagnostic` is not an "LSP diagnostic" though, and we try very hard to avoid imposing LSP specific concepts into the (generic) diagnostic structure. In this case it is probably fine since the "related information" seems pretty generic (could be used by non-LSP diagnostic producers).

If this does need to be in the top level structure it should follow the standard naming conventions (`related_information`, not `relatedInformation`). The latter style indicates that it is a field that maps directly to some LSP concept.

> `vim.Diagnostic` is not an "LSP diagnostic" though, and we try very hard to avoid imposing LSP specific concepts into the (generic) diagnostic structure. In this case it is probably fine since the "related information" seems pretty generic (could be used by non-LSP diagnostic producers).
> 
> If this does need to be in the top level structure it should follow the standard naming conventions (`related_information`, not `relatedInformation`). The latter style indicates that it is a field that maps directly to some LSP concept.

Yeah to me this seems general enough (I could imagine something like overseer.nvim make use of this). Thanks for the hint related to naming conventions, fixed!
Thanks for the review! I extended the tests in `lsp/diagnostic_spec.lua` now.

> Looks like this is missing the reverse mapping from vim to lsp. (And I'm starting to think we could just keep the original payload in a _lsp field on the vim.Diagnostic table, to ensure we send the original to the server and avoid any conversion errors)

Thanks for the hint - We already have `vim.diagnostic.user_data.lsp` which stored a subset of the original LSP diagnostic, I now simply made it store the entire table instead. That should also take care of the conversion back to LSP (Since `diagnostic_vim_to_lsp` already merges the `user_data.lsp` table
This has been closed since a request for information has not been answered for 30 days. It can be reopened when the requested information is provided.

performed_via_github_app.description: Automate your workflow from idea to production
performed_via_github_app.name: GitHub Actions

comment_regular_data.body: Hi everyone, I shifted focus to other projects and currently don't have time to work on this PR anymore. If somebody wants to take over, feel free to do so

title: feat(lsp): add related_information to vim.Diagnostic
